content.$t: month: 6, day: 6, headline: Early Days, text: Microsoft’s initial forays into what would become the smartphone market involved putting Windows Mobile onto other company’s devices. These were little more than PDAs that also happened to pack mobile functionality, like the T-Mobile MDA II and Hewlett Packard’s iPaq h6315. Both ran Windows Mobile 2003 PocketPC Phone Edition, which just rolls off the tongue., media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2006/01/BOTH6.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2006/01/BOTH6.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Microsoft’s initial forays into what would become the smartphone market involved putting Windows Mobile onto other company’s devices. These were little more than PDAs that also happened to pack mobile functionality, like the T-Mobile MDA II and Hewlett Packard’s iPaq h6315. Both ran Windows Mobile 2003 PocketPC Phone Edition, which just rolls off the tongue.

content.$t: month: 11, day: 16, headline: Windows Mobile 5, text: The smartphone world took another tentative step forward with Windows Mobile 5, which ran on devices like the Samsung BlackJack. Looking and sounding enough like a BlackBerry to warrant RIM to sue, it packed a QWERTY keyboard and a 320x240 display. , media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2006/12/blackjack-hands-on-1.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2006/12/blackjack-hands-on-1.jpg

gsx$text.$t: The smartphone world took another tentative step forward with Windows Mobile 5, which ran on devices like the Samsung BlackJack. Looking and sounding enough like a BlackBerry to warrant RIM to sue, it packed a QWERTY keyboard and a 320x240 display.

content.$t: month: 12, day: 12, headline: LG previews the future, text: LG’s Prada phone was the precursor to what we now think of when we talk about a smartphone. A black rectangle with an all-touch display, it was first shown off on December 12th, 2006. It wouldn’t be released until the following May, but Nokia failed to appreciate where the industry was headed., media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2007/01/front-flat1_20070118104240.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2007/01/front-flat1_20070118104240.jpg

gsx$text.$t: LG’s Prada phone was the precursor to what we now think of when we talk about a smartphone. A black rectangle with an all-touch display, it was first shown off on December 12th, 2006. It wouldn’t be released until the following May, but Nokia failed to appreciate where the industry was headed.

content.$t: month: 6, day: 29, headline: iPhone, text: Apple introduces the world to the iPhone, a touchscreen smartphone that was aimed squarely at high-end buyers. It makes Nokia's then flagship, the N95 (pictured on the previous slide), look dated in an instant., media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2007/01/apple-iphone-official-1.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2007/01/apple-iphone-official-1.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Apple introduces the world to the iPhone, a touchscreen smartphone that was aimed squarely at high-end buyers. It makes Nokia's then flagship, the N95 (pictured on the previous slide), look dated in an instant.

content.$t: month: 1, day: 25, headline: Ridin' high, text: Nokia started 2007 as the undisputed king of mobile phones, selling 106 million units worldwide. It would take a while for this trend to change, but these figures would begin sliding south as the smartphone age took hold., media: http://media.engadget.com/img/product/i1/n95-w4.jpg, mediacredit: Nokia N95, mediathumbnail: http://media.engadget.com/img/product/i1/n95-w4.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Nokia started 2007 as the undisputed king of mobile phones, selling 106 million units worldwide. It would take a while for this trend to change, but these figures would begin sliding south as the smartphone age took hold.

content.$t: month: 10, day: 22, headline: Android, text: The HTC Dream, the first smartphone produced by the Open Handset Alliance, backed by Google's Android operating system, goes on sale. , media: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/midas/78bba81c82d545d9ca26e1c5cf1db84f/200307348/frontview-g1-210.jpg, mediacaption: HTC, mediathumbnail: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/midas/78bba81c82d545d9ca26e1c5cf1db84f/200307348/frontview-g1-210.jpg

gsx$text.$t: The HTC Dream, the first smartphone produced by the Open Handset Alliance, backed by Google's Android operating system, goes on sale.

content.$t: month: 6, day: 30, headline: Kin...d of a disaster, text: Microsoft wanted to build a feature-rich, low-cost smartphone for teenagers, and so it bought Danger Incorporated for $500 million. Danger had been responsible for the design of the T-Mobile Sidekick and it was hoped that the firm could bring some low-end cool to Microsoft’s stuffed shirts. Executive meddling forced the team to rewrite the operating system and base it on Windows CE, despite having a working solution already. Delays, spiraling costs and customer apathy meant that the range was pulled from stores roughly a month after launch. , media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2010/06/kin-one-1.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2010/06/kin-one-1.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Microsoft wanted to build a feature-rich, low-cost smartphone for teenagers, and so it bought Danger Incorporated for $500 million. Danger had been responsible for the design of the T-Mobile Sidekick and it was hoped that the firm could bring some low-end cool to Microsoft’s stuffed shirts. Executive meddling forced the team to rewrite the operating system and base it on Windows CE, despite having a working solution already. Delays, spiraling costs and customer apathy meant that the range was pulled from stores roughly a month after launch.

content.$t: month: 9, day: 10, headline: Stephen Elop, text: Nokia saw its profits begin to erode as customers bought iOS and Android devices in growing numbers. In its panic, the company hired former Microsoft executive Stephen Elop to steady the ship. The new CEO quickly set about attempting to rescue Nokia’s flagging business, although his tenure would prove controversial. , media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2011/02/elop-lg.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2011/02/elop-lg.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Nokia saw its profits begin to erode as customers bought iOS and Android devices in growing numbers. In its panic, the company hired former Microsoft executive Stephen Elop to steady the ship. The new CEO quickly set about attempting to rescue Nokia’s flagging business, although his tenure would prove controversial.

content.$t: month: 2, day: 12, headline: Signed, sealed, delivered, text: Microsoft and Nokia enter into a “strategic partnership,” spearheaded by former Microsoft executive Stephen Elop. Nokia agrees to adopt Windows Phone as its smartphone operating system in exchange for providing its mobile expertise to Microsoft’s engineers. While both companies were distinct, their businesses were destined to become inexorably intertwined., media: https://www.microsoft.com/presspass/_resources/images/homepage/2011/hero/event_BallmerElop_hero.jpg, mediathumbnail: https://www.microsoft.com/presspass/_resources/images/homepage/2011/hero/event_BallmerElop_hero.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Microsoft and Nokia enter into a “strategic partnership,” spearheaded by former Microsoft executive Stephen Elop. Nokia agrees to adopt Windows Phone as its smartphone operating system in exchange for providing its mobile expertise to Microsoft’s engineers. While both companies were distinct, their businesses were destined to become inexorably intertwined.

content.$t: month: 9, day: 23, headline: What could have been, text: Nokia ships the N9 with its new operating system, MeeGo, designed as a fresh and modern platform that can take on iOS and Android. When we reviewed it, we said that it was the first competitive Nokia device that could stand equal to the iPhone. Stephen Elop decided to kill the project stone dead, adding that even if the N9 was a success, he would still push Nokia to using Microsoft software. , media: http://media.engadget.com/img/product/24/j6t/9fr9.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://media.engadget.com/img/product/24/j6t/9fr9.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Nokia ships the N9 with its new operating system, MeeGo, designed as a fresh and modern platform that can take on iOS and Android. When we reviewed it, we said that it was the first competitive Nokia device that could stand equal to the iPhone. Stephen Elop decided to kill the project stone dead, adding that even if the N9 was a success, he would still push Nokia to using Microsoft software.

content.$t: month: 2, day: 11, headline: Burning platform, text: Six months after joining Nokia and just days after the N9’s launch, Stephen Elop published his “burning platform” memo. The former Microsoft man said that the company was at a turning point and had already started to push the firm down a path toward using Microsoft’s mobile software in its phones., media: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/midas/8eb7e4d9c7ac8d1b8905d3c56c897f87/203725556/500056970.jpg, mediacredit: Getty Images, mediathumbnail: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/midas/8eb7e4d9c7ac8d1b8905d3c56c897f87/203725556/500056970.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Six months after joining Nokia and just days after the N9’s launch, Stephen Elop published his “burning platform” memo. The former Microsoft man said that the company was at a turning point and had already started to push the firm down a path toward using Microsoft’s mobile software in its phones.

content.$t: month: 11, day: 10, headline: The first child, text: In a rush, Nokia grabbed the body of the Nokia N9 and tweaked it just enough to get Windows Phone 7 to run on it. The device earned positive reviews from critics but was unable to garner a lot of interest from buyers. Subsequent devices would follow a similar path -- earning praise from those who used them and apathy from the wider world. Because it used Windows Phone 7, based on the old Windows CE kernel, it wouldn’t be able to receive software updates in the future. Which is one way to say thanks to your early adopters..., media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2011/10/nokia-lumia-1319626156-1319640491.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2011/10/nokia-lumia-1319626156-1319640491.jpg

gsx$text.$t: In a rush, Nokia grabbed the body of the Nokia N9 and tweaked it just enough to get Windows Phone 7 to run on it. The device earned positive reviews from critics but was unable to garner a lot of interest from buyers. Subsequent devices would follow a similar path -- earning praise from those who used them and apathy from the wider world. Because it used Windows Phone 7, based on the old Windows CE kernel, it wouldn’t be able to receive software updates in the future. Which is one way to say thanks to your early adopters...

content.$t: month: 1, day: 26, headline: Boom days are over, text: January 2012 marks the last time that Nokia would sell more than 100 million smartphones in a single financial quarter. It managed to get 113.5 million units out of the door in that three-month period, but sales will begin to dwindle rapidly after this point. , media: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/midas/8d0b575ec4e4a902396f7fae7dfcb368/203725562/phpfsygtz.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/midas/8d0b575ec4e4a902396f7fae7dfcb368/203725562/phpfsygtz.jpg

gsx$text.$t: January 2012 marks the last time that Nokia would sell more than 100 million smartphones in a single financial quarter. It managed to get 113.5 million units out of the door in that three-month period, but sales will begin to dwindle rapidly after this point.

content.$t: month: 9, day: 2, headline: Microsoft agrees to buy, text: Nokia, after several years of dwindling smartphone sales, withering profits and swinging job cuts, is bought by Microsoft. The software giant pledges to pay $4.99 billion for the business, plus another $2.18 billion to license its patents., media: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2012/09/elop-ballmer-1346872124.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2012/09/elop-ballmer-1346872124.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Nokia, after several years of dwindling smartphone sales, withering profits and swinging job cuts, is bought by Microsoft. The software giant pledges to pay $4.99 billion for the business, plus another $2.18 billion to license its patents.

content.$t: month: 4, day: 2, headline: Meet Mr. Nadella, text: Steve Ballmer had served as Microsoft CEO for 13 years before stepping down and sparking a race for a successor. Stephen Elop, now head of the firm’s device business, was one contender, while Satya Nadella was another. Nadella was, then, the company’s cloud and enterprise services chief. He had emerged as the anti-Ballmer, pushing Microsoft beyond selling Windows and Office discs toward cloud services like Azure and online services like Office 365., media: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/adam/b6d4d1526ee4e90db4d0ddf3dd67e05c/Nadella2_Web.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://o.aolcdn.com/hss/storage/adam/b6d4d1526ee4e90db4d0ddf3dd67e05c/Nadella2_Web.jpg

gsx$text.$t: Steve Ballmer had served as Microsoft CEO for 13 years before stepping down and sparking a race for a successor. Stephen Elop, now head of the firm’s device business, was one contender, while Satya Nadella was another. Nadella was, then, the company’s cloud and enterprise services chief. He had emerged as the anti-Ballmer, pushing Microsoft beyond selling Windows and Office discs toward cloud services like Azure and online services like Office 365.

content.$t: month: 4, day: 25, headline: Two become one, text: One of Satya Nadella’s first jobs is to welcome Stephen Elop back to the fold as the new head of Microsoft’s Devices group. It was hoped that, by bringing the phone business in-house, the company could boost profits and market share while cutting costs. , media: http://ncmedia.azureedge.net/ncmedia/2014/04/SatyaNadellaandStephenElop_Page.jpg, mediathumbnail: http://ncmedia.azureedge.net/ncmedia/2014/04/SatyaNadellaandStephenElop_Page.jpg

gsx$text.$t: One of Satya Nadella’s first jobs is to welcome Stephen Elop back to the fold as the new head of Microsoft’s Devices group. It was hoped that, by bringing the phone business in-house, the company could boost profits and market share while cutting costs.

content.$t: month: 4, day: 21, headline: A new low, text: Sales of Nokia-Microsoft–branded mobile phones has been in steady decline since 2011. Its most recent results showed that it sold just 18 million units, of which a meager 2.3 million were smartphones., media: http://o.aolcdn.com/dims-shared/dims3/GLOB/crop/5063x2567+0+0/resize/1400x710!/format/jpg/quality/85/http://hss-prod.hss.aol.com/hss/storage/midas/7dd4464c6abb4c78a7ceb624627759c2/203721944/RTX2AMB2.jpeg, mediathumbnail: http://o.aolcdn.com/dims-shared/dims3/GLOB/crop/5063x2567+0+0/resize/1400x710!/format/jpg/quality/85/http://hss-prod.hss.aol.com/hss/storage/midas/7dd4464c6abb4c78a7ceb624627759c2/203721944/RTX2AMB2.jpeg

gsx$text.$t: Sales of Nokia-Microsoft–branded mobile phones has been in steady decline since 2011. Its most recent results showed that it sold just 18 million units, of which a meager 2.3 million were smartphones.
